name: section merging
desc: Merge all sections; just one entry in the sections table.  Only affects readability slightly, so may not even be worth mitigating.  May affect some detection signatures if written to be section dependent.
mitigation: Manually modify with a PE editor.  Sections boundaries typically easy to identify by matching alignment (NT headers -> Optional header -> Section Alignment) and looking for large groupings of NULL bytes preceding each original section.

name: imports compression
desc: Imports are stored and loaded with a more compact import table format.  Each DLL needed by the executable is mentioned in the IAT, but only one function from each/most is imported; the rest are imported "manually" via GetProcAddress calls.
mitigation: Debug, dump (if necessary), and fix/reconstruct IAT.

name: imports by hash
desc: DLL loaded and then each export name is parsed until it matches a specific hash, instead of a GetProcAddress call. Also often seen used by shellcode, as it reduces the size of each import from a human-readable string to a sequence of four bytes.
mitigation: Debug, dump (if necessary), and fix/reconstruct IAT.

name: call optimisation
desc: Turn relative operands of jumps and calls into absolute (better compression).  May confuse some basic block detection algorithms.

name: resource(s) compression
desc: Compresses resources, avoiding critical ones (main icon, manifest, etc.)
mitigation: Debug and dump

name: token check
desc: Presence check to allow the program to run (ex: dongle, CD/DVD, key, file, network, etc.)
mitigation: Ensure item is present or patch (file or in-memory) the check to always succeed.

name: fingerprinting
desc: Token is specific to a hardware element (ex: disk, OS, CPU, NIC MAC, etc.)
mitigation: Ensure item is present or patch (file or in-memory) the check to always succeed.

name: demo mode
desc: Inclusion of a demo binary/mode that is executed when token is absent or not enough privileged.

name: Integrity check, data
desc: Check the contents of data sections are unmodified with checksum or hash.  Depending on implementation, may detect file, in-memory, or both.  Typically this does not affect analysis.
mitigation: Identify integrity check location and modify to always pass.

name: Integrity check, code
desc: Check that the unpacking code is unmodified.  Variation exists where unpacking code is part of the “key” used to unpack, therefore any Software Breakpoints during debugging causes unpacking to completely fail or result in malformed unpacked code.
mitigation:
Use software breakpoints sparingly.
Identify integrity check location and modify to always pass.

name: overlap
desc: Jumping after the first byte of an instruction.  Confuses some disassemblers.
mitigation:
Debug.
Use different disassembly engine or different options for your disassembly engine.

name: illusion
desc: Makes the analyst think something incorrect happened.  This is a general category of anti-analysis and may refer to any number of techniques.

name: junk
desc: Insertion of dummy code between relevant opcodes.  Can make signature writing more complex.

name: jumps
desc: Insertion of jumps to make analysis visually harder.

name: thunks
desc: Variation on “jump”; also used by some compilers for user-generated functions (ex: Visual Studio /INCREMENTAL)

name: polymorphism
desc: Different but equivalent code (2 packed files of the same source are different).  Mainly affects detection and similarity metrics, which makes for more manual analysis.
mitigation:
Use capability detections (ex: MAEC; CylanceV) and/or function-level fuzzy matching (ex: PIC Hash).
Use disassembler (or plugins) that allow saving function-level information and sharing/importing (ex: IDA MyNav; BinNavi)

name: self generation
desc: Packer stub generates polymorphic code on the fly (same file executes differently).  This is a general category of anti-analysis and may refer to any number of techniques.

name: packer virtualization
desc: Virtualizes [part of] packer stub code.  This is a general category of anti-analysis and may refer to any number of techniques.

name: virtualization
desc: Virtualizes original code; dumped code won’t work without VM code.  This is a general category of anti-analysis and may refer to any number of techniques.

name: stack strings
desc: Strings are built and decrypted on the stack at each use, then discarded (to avoid obvious references)
mitigation: Signature and script extraction and labeling.

name: faking
desc: Add fake code similar to known packers to fool identification.  Can confuse some automated unpackers.

name: blending in
desc: Add fake code similar to known goods to evade detection.

name: thread
desc: Use several parallel threads to make analysis harder.

name: timing, check delay
desc: Comparing time between two points to detect “unusual” execution, such as the (relative) massive delays introduced by debugging
mitigation:
1. Use a plugin.
2. Patch the comparison.

name: timing, at least
desc: Comparing single GetTickCount with some value to see if system has been started at least X amount ago.
mitigation:
1. snapshot analysis vm after letting it run for a while (hours) first
2. use tool/debugger that allows GetTickCount to always return a specific large number

name: timing, date check
desc: Calling GetSystemTime or equiv and only executing code if the current date/hour/minute/second passes some check. Often this is for running only after or only until a specific date.
mitigation: Look for API calls and modify inputs or comparison.

name: anti-debug, detect
desc: Detect the presence of an attached debugger (ex: IsDebuggerPresent)
mitigation: Use a plugin that takes care of this for you.

name: anti-debug, prevent
desc: Prevent a debugger to attach to the target itself or stay attached.  This is a general category of anti-analysis and may refer to any number of techniques.

name: anti-debug, nuisance
desc: Make debugger session difficult (BlockInput, slow down, etc.).  This is a general category of anti-analysis and may refer to any number of techniques.

name: anti-debug, thread
desc: Spawn a monitoring thread to detect tampering, breakpoints, etc.
mitigation: Disable the thread.

name: debug artifacts
desc: Detects a debugger by its artifact (window title, device driver, exports, etc.)
mitigation: Identify detection routine(s) and patch out or hardware breakpoint and modify register or stack values.

name: limitation
desc: Prevent the use of a tool via a specific limitation.  This is a general category of anti-analysis and may refer to any number of techniques.

name: exploit
desc: Prevent the use of a tool via a specific vulnerability.  This is a general category of anti-analysis and may refer to any number of techniques.

name: backdoor
desc: Detect or crash a tool via a specific backdoor.  This is a general category of anti-analysis and may refer to any number of techniques.

name: self-debugging
desc: Debug itself to prevent another debugger to be attached.
mitigation: Force attach debugger.  Not all debuggers support this option; see OllyMigrate in this case.

name: interrupt hooking
desc: Block interrupt 1 and/or 3 to prevent debuggers from working.

name: interrupt-based
desc: The unpacking code relies on use of int 1 or int 3, or it uses the interrupt vector table as part of the decryption “key” (Szor, p227)

name: tampering
desc: Erase or corrupt specific file parts to prevent rebuilding (header, packer stub, etc.)
mitigation: Identify which parts are corrupted; restart debug; breakpoint on modification of those blocks of memory and prevent modification.

name: anti-dump, imports
desc: Add obfuscation between imports calls and APIs (obfuscation, virtualization, stealing, etc.)

name: on-the-fly APIs
desc: API address is resolved before each use to prevent complete dumping

name: API hooking
desc: Alter API behavior (ex: redirect benign API to a critical one); sometimes used for anti-dump

name: static linking
desc: Copy locally the whole content of API code
mitigation: once one function is identified, use the fact that all functions for a statically linked library are in a contiguous memory region.

name: inlining
desc: variation of static linking where full API code inserted everywhere it would have been CALLed

name: relocate
desc: relocate API code in separate buffer (calls don’t lead to imported DLLs)

name: byte stealing
desc: Move the first bytes of the original code elsewhere (harder rebuilding and bypasses breakpoints)
mitigation: Breakpoint a few instructions into functions.

name: page guard
desc: Blocks of code are encrypted individually, and decrypted temporarily only upon execution

name: flow
desc: flow opcodes are removed and emulated (or decrypted) by the packer during execution

name: opcodes
desc: using different opcodes sets (ex: FPU, MMX, SSE) to block emulators

name: undoc
desc: use of rare or undocumented opcodes to block non-exhaustive emulators

name: anti-emulation, API
desc: unusual APIs are called to block non-exhaustive emulators (particularly anti-virus)

name: loop
desc: extra loops are added to make time-constraint emulators give up

name: dropper
desc: Original file is written to disk then executed.  May confuse some sandboxes, especially if the dropped executable must be provided specific arguments and the original dropper is not associated with the drop file(s).
mitigation:
1. Use a sandbox that captures full command line executions.
2. Identify intended arguments from static or debugger analysis

name: injection
desc: Original file is injected in existing process (nothing written to disk and possibly higher privs).
mitigation: Look for API calls: VirtualAllocEx, WriteProcessMemory, CreateRemoteThread, CreateRemoteThreadEx

name: embedded file hooking
desc: File handling APIs are modified to make embedded files usable like external ones

name: exception misdirection
desc: Using exception handling (SEH) to cause flow of program to non-obvious paths.
mitigation: Pass exceptions to program.  Breakpoint on new exception handlers.

name: conditional misdirection
desc: Conditional jumps are sometimes used to confuse disassembly engines, resulting in the wrong instruction boundaries and thus wrong mnemonic and operands; easy to “see” when jmp/jcc to a label+# (ex: JNE loc_401345fe+2)
mitigation: Debug; trace until condition (ex: section hop)

name: stack canary
desc: Similar to the anti-exploitation method of the same name, malware may try to detect mucking with values on the stack (Szor p227)

name: pipeline misdirection
desc: Taking advantage of pipelining in modern processors to misdirect debugging, emulation, or static analysis tools. An unpacker can assume a certain number of opcodes will be cached and then procede to overwrite them in memory, causing a debugger/emulator/analyzer to follow different code than is normally executed (Szor pp230-231)

name: BP clearing
desc: Intentionally clearing software or hardware breakpoints.

name: TIB-aware
desc: Accessing thread information (fs:[20h]) for debug detection or process obfuscation.

name: non-obvious loop escapes
desc: Using SEH or other methods to break out of a loop instead of a conditional jump.
mitigation: Breakpoint on exception handler(s)

name: modify self
desc: General class of techniques that modify the malware file(s) on disk.
mitigation: Breakpoint on MapViewOfFile[Ex]

name: prevent self-access
desc: "Protect" it's own process, preventing some analysis tools from working.
mitigation: Breakpoint on VirtualProtect[Ex]

name: nanomites
desc: int3 with code replacement table
mitigation: simply pass int3 to program?

name: self-unmapping
desc: UnmapViewOfFile() on itself
mitigation: Has to copy code and data to new/different segments, so dump those instead

name: stolen bytes (code splicing)
desc: First few instructions of original EP are incorporated into unpacking code.  May confuse some automated unpackers.
mitigation: Replace them manually

name: RtlAdjustPrivilege
desc: Calling RtlAdjustPrivilege to either prevent a debugger from attaching or to detect if a debugger is attached.
mitigation: Breakpoint on RtlAdjustPrivilege

name: Entry / start
desc: PUSHA
mitigation:
1. Look for POPA
2. Breakpoint on stack access

name: GET_BASE
desc: CALL to a POP; finds base of code or data, often the packed version of the code; also used often in obfuscated/packed shellcode

name: GETMODULE_HANDLE
desc: LoadLibrary API calls or direct access of kernel32 via PEB (fs[0]) pointers, used to rebuild IAT or just obfuscate library use

name: GETPROC_ADDRESS
desc: GetProcAddress API calls or “imports by hash”, used to rebuild IAT or just obfuscate API use

name: GET_APIS_WITH_CRC
desc: same as “imports by hash”
mitigation: Imports-by-hash can be a good way to signature if the hashing method or implementation is unique.

name: HOOK_API
desc: insert JMP/JCC instruction(s) at start of API calls

name: HOOK_INTERRUPT
desc: modification of interrupt vector or descriptor tables

name: HOOK_FILE_SYSTEM
desc: do something when particular file/dir is accessed; often through hooking certain API calls such as CreateFileA and CreateFileW

name: STEALTH
desc: Hiding on the system, for example by hooking NtQuerySystemInformation to hide a process name from TaskManager/tasklist

name: INIT_EXPLOIT
desc: Code associated with a known vulnerability

name: ENCODE_FILE
desc: Encode a file on disk, such as an implant’s config file
mitigation:
Debug.  Find API call that accesses file.
Encoding function could be signatured.

name: POLY_ENGINE / META_ENGINE
desc: Polymorphic engine. Often makes up 50% of the “code”. Look for code that creates instructions such as NOP, MOV, XOR

name: Stolen API Code (aka byte stealing)
desc: First few instructions or bytes of an API are executed in user code, allowing the IAT to point into the middle of an API function. This confuses IAT rebuilders such as ImpRec and Scylla.

name: Alignment
desc: Some analysis tools cannot handle binaries with misaligned sections.
mitigation: Use binary viewer that alerts on misaligned sections.  Fix manually.

name: SizeOfImage
desc: Changinging this value during run time can prevent some debuggers from attaching. see example assembly on page 1. Also confuses some unpackers and dumpers.
mitigation: Identify access to and modification of headers.

name: Modify PE Header
desc: More general case of above, where any part of the header could be changed or even erased. Example erasure assembly on page 2.
mitigation: Identify access to and modification of headers.

name: nanomites
desc: int3 with code replacement table; debugs itself; see page 2

name: guard pages
desc: blocks of code are encrypted individually, and decrypted temporarily only upon execution. One variant uses self-debugging to accomplish.
mitigation: Modify binary to touch all pages then pause; take memory snapshot.

name: pre-debug
desc: Unable to coax debugger to attach to process or to break until after the code of interest has been executed
mitigation:
1. patch binary, insert 0xcc
2. if it is a DLL, change EP to point to RET and add new export that points to the code of interest
3. use IDA or OllyDbg2

name: return obfuscation
desc: Overwrite the RET address on the stack or the code at the RET address.  Variation seen that writes to the start-up code or main module that called the malware's WinMain or DllMain
mitigation: When this is used as the tail transition, any of the typical tail transition heuristics can be used, such as section hop.

name: malloc
desc: Instead of unpacking into a pre-defined section/segment (ex: .text) of the binary, uses malloc() / VirtualAlloc() to create a new segment. This makes keeping track of memory locations across different runs more difficult, as there is no guarantee that malloc/VirtualAlloc will assign the same address range each time.
mitigation: Section hop, segment breakpoint, or trace until EIP in range

name: argument obfuscation
desc: simple number or string arguments to API calls are calculated at runtime, making static analysis more difficult.

name: Variable Recomposition
desc: Variables, often strings, are broken into multiple parts and store out of order, in different memory ranges, or both.  They must then be recomposed before use.

name: Value-Dependent Jumps
desc: Explicit use of computed values for control flow, often many times in the same basic block or function.

name: Deposited Keys
desc: Parts of the code and/or data is encrypted or otherwise relies on data external to the file itself.  For example, malware that contains code that is encrypted with a key that is downloaded from a server; malware that only runs if certain other software is installed on the system; or malware that reads certain attributes of the system (BIOS version string, hostname, etc) and then encrypts portions of its code or data using those attributes as input, thus preventing itself from being able to be run on a different system, such as a sandbox.

name: Secure Triggers
desc: Code and/or data is encrypted until the underlying system satisfies a preselected condition unknown to the analyst.  This is a form of Deposited Keys.

name: Minification
desc: Per wikipedia, minification is 'the process of removing all unnecessary characters from source code without changing its functionality.'  A simple example is when all the unecessary whitespace and comments are removed.  This is distinguished from compression in that it neither adds to nor changes the code seen by the interpreter.  Minification is often used for malware written in interpreted languages, such as JavaScript, PHP, or Python.  Legitimate code that is transmitted many times a second, such as JavaScript on websites, often uses minification to simply reduce the number of bytes transmitted.
mitigation: Mitigation, often called 'unminifying', 'prettifying', or 'beautifying' is trivial, though may require a language-specific tool (ex: JSBeautifier).
